title: Judges Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 7.

questions.question: Where did Gideon and the people pitch their camp according to Judges 7:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Beside the well of Harod
questions.explanation: Judges 7:1 states that Gideon and the people pitched beside the well of Harod.

questions.question: Why did the LORD say the people with Gideon were too many in Judges 7:2?
options: Israel might boast they saved themselves
They would steal from each other
questions.correctAnswer: Israel might boast they saved themselves
questions.explanation: Judges 7:2 explains God’s concern that Israel might boast saying, 'Mine own hand hath saved me.'

questions.question: How many men left when those fearful and afraid were told to depart in Judges 7:3?
questions.explanation: Judges 7:3 says twenty-two thousand returned home because they were fearful and afraid.

questions.question: According to Judges 7:6, how many men lapped water with their hands to their mouths like a dog?
questions.explanation: Judges 7:6 states that three hundred men lapped water with their hands to their mouths.

questions.question: What did the LORD say about the three hundred men who lapped water in Judges 7:7?
options: By them God would save Gideon
questions.correctAnswer: By them God would save Gideon
questions.explanation: Judges 7:7 says the LORD would save Gideon by the three hundred men who lapped water.

questions.question: Who accompanied Gideon down to the Midianite camp in Judges 7:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Phurah, his servant
questions.explanation: Judges 7:10 mentions Gideon was told to go with his servant Phurah if he feared to go down alone.

questions.question: What did the man in the Midianite camp dream about in Judges 7:13?
options: A cake of barley bread tumbling into the host
A lion roaring over the camp
A sword falling from the sky
questions.correctAnswer: A cake of barley bread tumbling into the host
questions.explanation: Judges 7:13 describes a dream where a cake of barley bread tumbled into the Midianite camp and overturned a tent.

questions.question: How did Gideon divide the three hundred men in Judges 7:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Into three companies
questions.explanation: Judges 7:16 states Gideon divided the three hundred men into three companies.

questions.question: What did Gideon and his men carry in their hands during the attack in Judges 7:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Trumpets, empty pitchers, and lamps
questions.explanation: Judges 7:16 explains they had trumpets, empty pitchers, and lamps within the pitchers.

questions.question: What did Gideon and his men shout when they blew the trumpets in Judges 7:20?
options: The sword of the LORD, and of Gideon
questions.correctAnswer: The sword of the LORD, and of Gideon
questions.explanation: Judges 7:20 records their cry as 'The sword of the LORD, and of Gideon.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 7:21, the Midianite host stood firm and did not flee.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 7:21 states that all the host ran, cried, and fled.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 7:22 says the LORD caused the Midianites to fight among themselves.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 7:22 explains the LORD set every man's sword against his fellow causing confusion in Midian's camp.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 7:23 mentions that men from Naphtali, Asher, and Manasseh pursued the Midianites after the battle.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 7:23 states that men from these tribes gathered and pursued the Midianites.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Judges 7:25 says Gideon’s men took two princes of the Midianites named ______ and ______.
questions.correctAnswer: Oreb and Zeeb
questions.explanation: Judges 7:25 names the two princes as Oreb and Zeeb.

questions.question: According to Judges 7:5, how were the men who drank water categorized?
options: Those who lapped water with tongue like a dog and those who bowed down on knees to drink
Those who drank quickly and those who drank slowly
Those who drank from the river and those who drank from a well
Those who drank alone and those who drank in groups
questions.correctAnswer: Those who lapped water with tongue like a dog and those who bowed down on knees to drink
questions.explanation: Judges 7:5 describes two types of drinking: lapping with tongue like a dog and bowing on knees to drink.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is anxious about facing a difficult challenge. Based on Judges 7:2-3, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's plan?
options: God may reduce our resources so we rely on Him alone.
We should depend on our own strength and numbers to succeed.
Fear is a sign that God does not support our efforts.
God will always increase our resources for victory.
questions.correctAnswer: God may reduce our resources so we rely on Him alone.
questions.explanation: Judges 7:2-3 shows God instructing Gideon to reduce the number of men to prevent Israel from boasting that their own strength saved them, teaching reliance on God's power rather than human might.

questions.question: How does Judges 7:5-7 teach us about discerning God’s guidance in times of decision?
options: God tests us through unexpected methods to show His power.
We should always choose the biggest group for strength.
Decisions should be based on popular opinion.
God prefers those who drink water first.
questions.correctAnswer: God tests us through unexpected methods to show His power.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-7 describe God's specific test at the water, selecting 300 men who lapped water like dogs, illustrating that God's criteria may differ from human expectations to demonstrate His power.

questions.question: When feeling weak or inadequate for a task, what encouragement does Judges 7:9-11 offer about God’s support?
options: God strengthens us after we hear His promises.
We should never ask for help or confirmation.
Fear means we should avoid the task.
Only leaders without doubt can succeed.
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens us after we hear His promises.
questions.explanation: In Judges 7:9-11, God tells Gideon to go with his servant to hear the enemy's talk to strengthen his hands, showing God provides reassurance and strength in moments of fear.

questions.question: How does the dream and its interpretation in Judges 7:13-15 illustrate the role of faith in God’s promises?
options: Faith grows when we recognize God’s hand in events around us.
Dreams are the only way God communicates His will.
We should only trust visible strength, not dreams.
Prophecies are irrelevant to daily life.
questions.correctAnswer: Faith grows when we recognize God’s hand in events around us.
questions.explanation: Judges 7:13-15 shows a dream interpreted as God's deliverance, which prompted Gideon to worship and confidently lead, teaching that recognizing God's signs strengthens faith.

questions.question: What lesson about obedience and leadership can be learned from Gideon’s strategy in Judges 7:16-18?
options: Obedience to God’s plan, even if unusual, leads to victory.
Leaders should always act independently without instructions.
Traditional weapons are necessary for success.
Planning is not important in spiritual battles.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s plan, even if unusual, leads to victory.
questions.explanation: Judges 7:16-18 describes Gideon following God's unconventional battle plan involving trumpets, pitchers, and lamps, showing that trusting and obeying God’s instructions is essential.

questions.question: Based on Judges 7:19-22, how does God demonstrate that victory comes from Him, not human strength?
options: God caused the enemy to fight among themselves leading to their defeat.
The large army defeated Gideon’s small group by numbers.
Gideon’s army used superior weapons to win.
Victory was due to surprise alone.
questions.correctAnswer: God caused the enemy to fight among themselves leading to their defeat.
questions.explanation: Verses 19-22 show God setting the enemy’s sword against each other, causing confusion and flight, demonstrating that victory belongs to God, not human power.

questions.question: A believer feels small and insignificant in their service to God. What does Judges 7:7 and 7:8 teach about faith and service?
options: God can use a small faithful group to accomplish great things.
Only large groups can make a difference in God’s work.
Success depends solely on human resources.
questions.correctAnswer: God can use a small faithful group to accomplish great things.
questions.explanation: Judges 7:7-8 shows God choosing 300 men from thousands for victory, teaching that God values faithfulness over numbers in service.

questions.question: How does the sending of messengers in Judges 7:24 reflect the importance of fellowship and cooperation in God’s work?
options: Unity and cooperation strengthen the community’s witness and success.
Each group should act independently without coordination.
Fellowship is not important in spiritual battles.
Only the initial group should do the work.
questions.correctAnswer: Unity and cooperation strengthen the community’s witness and success.
questions.explanation: In Judges 7:24, Gideon calls the men of Ephraim to join the battle, highlighting the biblical principle of believers working together in unity.

questions.question: What does Judges 7:1-2 teach about humility and contentment in trusting God’s provision?
options: We should be content with what God provides and trust His timing.
Always seek to increase your own resources by any means.
Self-reliance is better than trusting God.
God’s help is only for the strongest and greatest.
questions.correctAnswer: We should be content with what God provides and trust His timing.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 show God intentionally reducing Israel’s army to teach reliance on Him, encouraging humility and trust rather than pride in numbers.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 7:21-23, the victory over Midian was a result of Israel’s superior military strength.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 7:21-23 clearly states that the LORD caused confusion among Midian, leading to their defeat, showing victory was by God’s power, not human strength.

questions.question: True or False: Gideon’s obedience to God’s command to reduce his army was driven by fear and distrust in God’s power according to Judges 7:3-7.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 7:3-7 shows Gideon obeying God’s instructions to reduce the army, demonstrating trust and humility rather than fear or distrust.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Judges 7:16-20, Gideon’s men held empty __________ with lamps inside to create light and confusion in the enemy camp.
questions.correctAnswer: pitchers
questions.explanation: Judges 7:16-20 describes Gideon’s men holding empty pitchers with lamps inside to surprise and confuse the enemy.

questions.question: How does Judges 7:25 teach the importance of integrity and justice in leadership after victory?
options: Gideon executed justice by capturing and punishing the enemy leaders.
Leaders should ignore consequences after battle.
Victory absolves all responsibility for justice.
Leaders should avoid dealing with enemies personally.
questions.correctAnswer: Gideon executed justice by capturing and punishing the enemy leaders.
questions.explanation: Judges 7:25 shows Gideon bringing the heads of enemy princes to Israel, emphasizing accountability and justice as part of godly leadership.

questions.question: According to Judges 7:17-18, what role does unity in action play in Christian witness and service?
options: Unity in following God’s lead amplifies the impact of service.
Individual actions are more important than group unity.
Each person should act independently without coordination.
questions.correctAnswer: Unity in following God’s lead amplifies the impact of service.
questions.explanation: Verses 17-18 show Gideon instructing men to act together exactly as he does, illustrating the power of unified obedience in God’s work.

questions.question: What principle about perseverance through trials can be drawn from Gideon’s experience in Judges 7:11-15?
options: God strengthens us through confirmation and worship to face challenges.
Doubt should cause us to abandon our calling.
We should rely only on our own strength in trials.
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens us through confirmation and worship to face challenges.
questions.explanation: Judges 7:11-15 shows Gideon gaining strength after hearing the dream’s interpretation and worshipping, teaching that God provides reassurance and perseverance.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 7.

questions.question: Why did the LORD tell Gideon that the people with him were too many to defeat Midian?
options: So Israel would not boast they saved themselves
Because the Midianites had supernatural powers
Because the people were not trained for battle
So Gideon would feel more confident
questions.correctAnswer: So Israel would not boast they saved themselves
questions.explanation: Judges 7:2 states that the people were too many so that Israel would not say their own hand saved them, emphasizing God's sovereignty.

questions.question: How many men remained with Gideon after those who were fearful and afraid left?
questions.explanation: Judges 7:3 says 22,000 returned home, leaving 10,000 with Gideon after the fearful departed.

questions.question: What was the distinguishing method used at the water to further reduce the number of men with Gideon?
options: Whether a man lapped water with his tongue like a dog
Whether a man drank water standing
Whether a man bathed in the water
Whether a man fasted instead of drinking
questions.correctAnswer: Whether a man lapped water with his tongue like a dog
questions.explanation: Judges 7:5-6 describes how the LORD instructed Gideon to separate those who lapped water like a dog from those who kneeled to drink.

questions.question: How many men did Gideon keep after the water test?
questions.explanation: Judges 7:6 states that only 300 men lapped the water with their hands to their mouths, and these were kept.

questions.question: What was the purpose of reducing the number of men to 300 according to the LORD?
options: To ensure the victory was attributed to God
To prevent overcrowding in the camp
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure the victory was attributed to God
questions.explanation: Judges 7:7 explains that God would save Israel by the 300 men so that the victory would not be credited to human strength.

questions.question: What items did Gideon's men carry into battle?
questions.correctAnswer: Trumpets, empty pitchers, and lamps
questions.explanation: Judges 7:16 describes how Gideon divided the men and gave each a trumpet, empty pitcher, and a lamp inside the pitcher.

questions.question: What was the significance of the dream about the barley cake in the Midianite camp?
options: It foretold the defeat of Midian by Gideon
It was a warning of famine
It symbolized peace between Israel and Midian
It predicted the destruction of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It foretold the defeat of Midian by Gideon
questions.explanation: Judges 7:13-14 recounts a Midianite's dream interpreted as the sword of Gideon delivering Midian into Israel’s hands.

questions.question: What was Gideon's response upon hearing the interpretation of the dream?
options: He worshipped and encouraged the men to arise
He doubted and delayed the attack
He sent spies to confirm the dream
questions.correctAnswer: He worshipped and encouraged the men to arise
questions.explanation: Judges 7:15 states that Gideon worshipped and then called the men to arise because the LORD had delivered Midian.

questions.question: What was the battle cry Gideon and his men shouted when they blew the trumpets and broke the pitchers?
options: "The sword of the LORD, and of Gideon"
questions.correctAnswer: "The sword of the LORD, and of Gideon"
questions.explanation: Judges 7:18 and 7:20 record the men shouting this phrase as a declaration of divine victory.

questions.question: What happened to the Midianite army after Gideon's surprise attack?
options: They panicked, fled, and turned their swords against each other
questions.correctAnswer: They panicked, fled, and turned their swords against each other
questions.explanation: Judges 7:21-22 explains that the Midianites fled and the LORD caused them to fight among themselves.

questions.question: Which tribes gathered to pursue the fleeing Midianites after the battle?
questions.correctAnswer: Naphtali, Asher, and Manasseh
questions.explanation: Judges 7:23 states that men from these tribes gathered to pursue the Midianites.

questions.question: What strategic location did Gideon ask the men of Ephraim to take control of during the battle?
options: The waters unto Bethbarah and Jordan
questions.correctAnswer: The waters unto Bethbarah and Jordan
questions.explanation: Judges 7:24 indicates Gideon sent messengers to seize these waters to block the Midianite retreat.

questions.question: Who were the two Midianite princes captured and killed by Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Oreb and Zeeb
questions.explanation: Judges 7:25 records the capture and execution of these two princes during the chase.

questions.question: True or False: Gideon was completely confident and did not require any reassurance before attacking the Midianite camp.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 7:9-11 shows God reassured Gideon and sent him with his servant Phurah to hear the enemy's words to strengthen his hand.

questions.question: What literary device is employed in Judges 7 by reducing the number of soldiers from thousands to three hundred to illustrate God's power?
questions.correctAnswer: Typology
questions.explanation: The drastic reduction symbolizes God's sovereign power working through weakness, a typological theme echoed in later scriptures like 1 Corinthians 1:27.

questions.question: How does the use of lamps within pitchers in Gideon's battle plan serve as a foreshadowing in biblical imagery?
options: It prefigures the light of Christ shining in darkness
It symbolizes the destruction of idols
It represents the burning of the Midianite tents
It reflects the ancient Near Eastern mourning rituals
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the light of Christ shining in darkness
questions.explanation: The hidden lamps revealed at night symbolize illumination and divine guidance, a motif developed in the New Testament (John 8:12).

theological.title: Judges Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the reason God gave for reducing Gideon's army before the battle with the Midianites?
options: The people were too many, lest Israel boast against God
The army was not well trained
questions.correctAnswer: The people were too many, lest Israel boast against God
questions.explanation: Judges 7:2 says God told Gideon the people were too many so Israel would not claim their own hand saved them. Consistent with 1 Corinthians 1:27-29 emphasizing God’s power over human boasting, Romans 3:27 notes boasting excluded, and Psalm 20:7 trusting in God’s power rather than numbers.

questions.question: How many men remained after God told Gideon to send away those who were fearful and afraid?
questions.explanation: Judges 7:3 records 22,000 left and 10,000 remained after fearful men departed. This reduction illustrates God’s sovereignty in salvation (Isaiah 10:22), and reminds of Jesus’ words about the narrow way in Matthew 7:13-14.

questions.question: What was the criterion God used at the water to further reduce Gideon's army?
options: How men drank water—lapping like a dog or bowing to drink
Whether men could carry their weapons
Whether men could blow a trumpet
questions.correctAnswer: How men drank water—lapping like a dog or bowing to drink
questions.explanation: Judges 7:5-6 shows God distinguished men by their manner of drinking water. This selection symbolizes God’s sovereign election (Deuteronomy 7:7-8), and God's power working through the weak (1 Corinthians 1:27).

questions.question: How many men remained after God selected those who lapped water with their hands?
questions.explanation: Judges 7:6 records only 300 men lapped water with their hands and were chosen. This small number shows God’s power to save with few, reflecting the divine paradox in 1 Corinthians 1:27 and echoing Gideon's faith as an example in Hebrews 11:32.

questions.question: What did God say He would do with the 300 men who lapped water?
options: He would save Israel by them and deliver Midian into their hands
He would test their faith in battle
He would use them as scouts
questions.correctAnswer: He would save Israel by them and deliver Midian into their hands
questions.explanation: Judges 7:7 states God would save Israel by the 300 men and deliver Midian into their hands. This demonstrates God’s saving power through weak means, consistent with Psalm 33:16-17 and Zechariah 4:6.

questions.question: What did Gideon do after hearing the interpretation of the dream about the barley loaf?
options: He worshipped and encouraged his men to arise
He doubted and delayed the attack
He consulted the priests for confirmation
He sent spies to verify the enemy’s camp
questions.correctAnswer: He worshipped and encouraged his men to arise
questions.explanation: Judges 7:15 shows Gideon worshipped God and urged his men to arise after hearing the dream interpretation. This act reveals the importance of faith and worship preceding obedience (Psalm 95:6, Hebrews 12:28).

questions.question: What tactical items did Gideon give to his 300 men for the attack?
questions.correctAnswer: Trumpets, empty pitchers, and lamps
questions.explanation: Judges 7:16 describes the men carrying trumpets, empty pitchers, and lamps inside the pitchers. This unconventional weaponry illustrates God’s use of weakness and surprise in salvation, paralleling Psalm 144:1 and 2 Corinthians 12:9.

questions.question: What was the battle cry Gideon’s men shouted when they blew their trumpets?
options: "The sword of the LORD, and of Gideon"
questions.correctAnswer: "The sword of the LORD, and of Gideon"
questions.explanation: Judges 7:18 and 7:20 record the men shouting "The sword of the LORD, and of Gideon," emphasizing divine empowerment in battle. This declares God’s sovereignty and messianic authority, reflecting Isaiah 42:1 and Hebrews 4:12.

questions.question: What was the immediate effect on the Midianite army when Gideon’s men blew the trumpets and broke the pitchers?
options: They panicked, cried out, and fled
questions.correctAnswer: They panicked, cried out, and fled
questions.explanation: Judges 7:21 states the Midianites ran in confusion after the attack began. This demonstrates God’s ability to cause enemies to defeat themselves (2 Chronicles 20:22, Exodus 14:24), showing His power in salvation.

questions.question: According to Judges 7, who did God cause to fight each other during the battle?
questions.correctAnswer: The Midianites themselves
questions.explanation: Judges 7:22 reveals God set every man’s sword against his fellow among the Midianites, causing internal strife. This reflects God’s control over human events (Romans 9:17) and His use of judgment against enemies (Psalm 35:8).

questions.question: From which tribes did the men who pursued the fleeing Midianites come?
questions.correctAnswer: Naphtali, Asher, and Manasseh
questions.explanation: Judges 7:23 states the men from Naphtali, Asher, and all Manasseh pursued the Midianites. This shows the unity of Israel under God’s deliverance, consistent with Psalm 133:1 and Ephesians 4:3-6.

questions.question: What was the significance of Gideon sending messengers to mount Ephraim during the pursuit?
options: To prevent the Midianites from crossing the Jordan River
To warn them of an ambush
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent the Midianites from crossing the Jordan River
questions.explanation: Judges 7:24 shows Gideon instructed Ephraim to seize the waters to block Midianite retreat. This strategic move reflects God’s providence and the church’s role in spiritual warfare (2 Corinthians 10:4-5).

questions.question: Who were the two Midianite princes captured and killed by the Israelites?
questions.correctAnswer: Oreb and Zeeb
questions.explanation: Judges 7:25 records the capture and death of princes Oreb and Zeeb. Their defeat symbolizes God’s judgment on oppressors, as in Isaiah 10:27 and Romans 12:19.

questions.question: What does Gideon's reduction of his army illustrate about God's method of salvation?
options: God often saves through weakness and few numbers
God requires large armies for victory
God only uses kings to save
questions.correctAnswer: God often saves through weakness and few numbers
questions.explanation: The drastic reduction of Gideon's army to 300 men (Judges 7:7) illustrates God's power in saving through weakness, consistent with 1 Corinthians 1:27-29 and Zechariah 4:6, emphasizing reliance on God rather than human might.

questions.question: What attribute of God is most clearly revealed in His instruction to reduce Gideon's army?
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereignty over salvation
questions.explanation: God’s command to reduce the army (Judges 7:2-7) highlights His absolute sovereignty in salvation, in line with Romans 9:15-16 and Ephesians 1:11, showing God’s control over the means and outcome of salvation.

questions.question: How does the dream and its interpretation in Judges 7 serve a Christological or messianic purpose?
options: It symbolizes God’s sovereign deliverer who defeats enemies
It predicts the coming of a new temple
It foretells the birth of the Messiah in Bethlehem
It describes the destruction of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God’s sovereign deliverer who defeats enemies
questions.explanation: The dream of the barley cake crushing the Midianite camp (Judges 7:13-14) symbolizes God's sovereign deliverer defeating enemies, prefiguring Christ’s victory over sin and death (John 16:33, Revelation 19:11).
